issues.title: feedback on IETF draft (March 5), Sections 4 and 5
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
I'm not sure I got everything, but I'm listing the edits I see in the order of appearance, marking the edits which I think are higher importance with (*) and highest importance with (**).

Secs 4.1and 4.2:  

Can we add in 4.1 that we rely on the underlying KEM to be CCA secure?

Sec 4.2, BUKEM (*):  

Can we add that we only care about uniform encodings of public keys, and not ciphertexts?  We refer to KEMELEON for how BUKEM is to be implemented, but does KEMELEON give an option that only public keys are encoded as bitstrings but ciphertexts are not?  If you switch on both of these randomized encodings then you will add computational/bandwidth overhead in Encaps and Decaps, which is not needed.  

It would also be better, I think, if the requirements that we need of this (BU)KEM module are stated more precisely.  Right now the draft says:  "Specifically, public keys and ciphertexts are indistinguishable from random strings of bytes (of the same length). This is crucial for the security of QUAKE."  This is not exactly right:  What is crucial is that (1) public keys are indistinguishable from random strings [...], and (2) ciphertexts are anonymous.  (And that anonymity as well as standard security hold under CCA attack.)

Sec 5.1, CPace:

I don't see definition of transcript(...) function, i.e. is transcript(Ya,Yb) just Ya|Yb?

Sec 5.2, QUAKE, in Init and Respond:  

- (*) value "r" is missing in the KDF.Extract inputs that compute prk_r_pad

- "r_pad" and "s_pad" are not consistently named:  
r_pad is computed on input "r", and it is used to compute T from pk in Init and pk from T in Respond;
s_pad is computed on input "T", and it is used to compute s from r in Init and r from s i Respond;

To make this terminology more consistent, how about naming these pads from the input used to compute them, because this part will be the same in Init and Respond?  

Assuming that we rename "s_pad" to "T_pad", currently you derive the two values like this, for x=s and x=T:
prk_x_pad = KDF.Extract(PRS , DST | "QUAKE" | x | fullsid)
x_pad = KDF.Expand(prk_x_pad, DST | "x_pad", [x_pad_length])

Two proposals about the above:
(1) Switch the order of x and fullsid inputs in KDF.Extract, because if we use a convention that identifiers come first and high-entropy values last, then fullsid is an identifier and x is the high-entropy secret.
(2) You can skip the info = DST | "x_pad" input in KDF.Expand, because the labels are already used in the KDF.Extract that created prk_x_pad, and this prk_x_pad value is not used anywhere else.

In other words, I propose the following syntax:
prk_x_pad = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "QUAKE" || fullsid || x)
x_pad = KDF.Expand(prk_s_pad, [x_pad_length])


Sec 5.2, QUAKE, in Respond and Finish:

- (**)  you changed the protocol to eliminate the authentication tag, but that's not what NoIC does, and I don't think this is what we agreed on.   In other words, right now resp_msg is just a KEM ciphertext "ct".  Instead, it should be resp_msg = ct || h, where h is computed as
h = KDF.Expand(prk_sk, "confirm", Nkc)

- (**)  in Finish the BUKEM.Decaps doesn't handle the decapsulation error, and you removed error-handling due to mismatch in the "h" key confirmation message (because you removed that message).  Both should be handled by sampling and returning a random key.

- You currently create the session key like this:
prk_sk = KDF.Extract(k || PRS, DST || "QUAKE" || fullsid)
key = KDF.Expand(prk_sk, DST || "sk", Nkey)

For consistency with the usage of Extract+Expand in 2Feistel hashes, and because Expand doesn't need the "DST" input, I propose to change it to:
prk_sk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "QUAKE" || fullsid || k)
key = KDF.Expand(prk_sk, "sk", Nkey)


Sec 5.3, CPaceQUAKE:

- (*) in the diagram picture just above the line "Unlike QUAKE, [...]", the session key output by CPaceQUAKE is still the session key of QUAKE, but it should be instead a hash of (fullsid, tr1, tr2, SK12, SK2)

- in the same diagram there is a missing closing bracket in the "H(fullsid,PRS,tr1,SK1" expression on the left

- (*) extended_sid_prk is computed using different ikm input in Respond (ikm=nil) and InitiatorFinish (ikm+

- In Respond and InitiatorFinish you currently derive extended_sid like this:
extended_sid_prk = KDF.Extract(s1||s2, DST) 
extended_sid = KDF.Expand(extended_sid_prk, DST||"SID", 32)

To be consistent with the format used above, I propose to change it to:
extended_sid_prk = KDF.Extract(s1||s2, DST||"SID") 
extended_sid = KDF.Expand(extended_sid_prk, 32)

- (*) you have a line computing client_key in Respond, but that's too early:  this line is missing inputs and should be deleted
   
- (*) in ResponderFinish you should rename "client_key" to "server_key"

- (*) why are all the RO hashes above handled via KDF=HMAC Extract+Expand calls, but the hashes deriving PRS2 and the "key" output are using hash "H" directly?  This does not seem consistent.

First, to be consistent with the [HKL24] Hybrid construction, we should do this:
key1A = KDF.Expand(key1,"prs",Nkey)
key1B = KDF.Expand(key1,"outputkey",Nkey)

Second, to be consistent with the same implementation of random oracle hashes via KDF(=HMAC) as is used in other cases, we should set:
PRS2_prk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "PRS2" || fullsid || msg1 || msg2 || key1A) 
PRS2 = KDF.Expand(PRS2_prk, Nkey)
and:
sessionkey_prk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "sessionkey" || fullsid || msg1 || msg2 || msg3 || msg4 || key1B || key2) 
[client/server]_key = KDF.Expand(sessionkey_prk, Nkey)

issues.body: Sorry for not catching this before, but this version of our protocol is actually CPaceOQUAKE (and the subprotocol is OQUAKE). The aPAKE is CPaceOQUAKE+. So QUAKE -> OQUAKE.

issues.title: Refrain from using the term binary uniform kem to refer to a kem that is not uniform
issues.author: jellevos
issues.body: I think we should change the wording of Section 4.2. The KEM that we need (as pointed out by Stanislaw) does not require ciphertext uniformity; only ciphertext anonymity. If we want to explicitly mention this, then maybe we can call it 'Binary KEM with uniformity properties' instead of uniform KEM.

issues.title: My feedback on edits to sections 4 and 5 from Sunday 3/9
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
copying here the comments I sent in an email sent Sunday 3/9
(these are comments to sections 4 and 5)

*****************

lines 215 and 217:  We don't need ciphertexts to be indistinguishable
from random strings, we only need public keys to have this property,
and anonymity doesn't follow from IND-CCA.  Here's my proposal for
lines 212-217:

**
A binary uniform KEM supports the same functions as defined above for
a KEM, and it must also be IND-CCA secure, but it must also achieve
two additional security properties.  Namely, in addition to IND-CCA
security, a binary uniform KEM requires that:
1. Public keys are indistinguishable from random strings of bytes (of
the same length); and
2. Ciphertexts are anonymous in the presence of chosen ciphertext
attack (ANO-CCA).
**

lines 219-220, I propose the following edits:

**
These additional properties are crucial for the security of QUAKE. In
other words, one MUST NOT use a KEM that has no uniform public keys
and no anonymous ciphertexts in place of a uniform KEM.
**

line 517 (QUAKE.Respond):  prk_s_pad computation should be aligned
with QUAKE.Init, i.e. it should be:
prk_s_pad = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "QUAKE" || fullsid || T)

line 521:  input r is missing, and also should be aligned with
QUAKE.Init, i.e. it should be:
prk_T_pad = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "QUAKE" || fullsid || r)

lines 530 and 571 (computation of h in QUAKE.Respond and h_expected in
QUAKE.Finish):
for consistency with how you compute variable "key" in QUAKE, you
should compute variables h and h_expected, in lines 520 and 571, like
this:
h = KDF.Expand(prk_sk, DST || "confirm", Nkey)
h_expected = KDF.Expand(prk_sk, DST || "confirm", Nkey)

[Discussion: right now you prepend the DST domain separation tag into
the "key" computation, but not the "h" computation.  I was arguing
that you can skip this DST moniker in all KDF.Expand's because you
have them in KDF.Extract's but it's OK to keep them too:  I think you
want to keep them as inputs to both KDF.Extract and KDF.Expand calls,
which is fine, so just to make the format consistent add the same
DST-prefix to the "domain separator" input "confirm" in KDF.Expand
that computes the "h" variable]

lines 721 and 724 (key1A computation):  because value key1A is used as
a key in PRS2 computation, and for consistency with names of other
labels, I suggest changing label "prs" to "prskey"

lines 730-731 and 771-772 (PRS2 computation):
I know I'm changing my own previous edit recommendation, but to make
these calls consistent with how you compute everything else (e.g.
server_key and client_key), I suggest changing the current lines:
PRS2_prk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "PRS2" || fullsid || msg1 || msg2 || key1A)
PRS2 = KDF.Expand(PRS2_prk, Nkey)
as follows:
PRS2_prk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "CPaceQUAKE" || fullsid || msg1 ||
msg2 || key1A)
PRS2 = KDF.Expand(PRS2_prk, DST || "PRS2", Nkey)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Addressed in #15

issues.title: comments to Section 6
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
section 6:
In the first paragraph, maybe it would be useful to add a
disambiguation that in this section we use "regular" KEM, i.e. not
BUKEM?  Perhaps a note to that effect in brackets?

section 6.1 and 6.2:
Change "U" to "userID" (or any other name for this) in the inputs to
GenVerifiers and GenVerifierMaterial:  The "U" moniker is used in all
protocols in section 5, i.e. CPace, QUAKE, and CPaceQUAKE, as a
"client" identifier, i.e. identifier of a machine on which user
happens to run the authentication code.  This could be, for example,
an end-point of a TLS session, and could be implemented via a binder
to the TLS session.  By contrast, in 6.1, the "U" moniker is a *user*
identifier, i.e. it is a long-term string which the server uses to
identify some user account.  This identifier is long-term and is
independent of the machine on which the user runs the authentication.
So it is a logically different value and should not be confused with
the machine identifiers "U" and "S".    Now, in practice "S" might be
a long-term identifier, for example it could be the DNS name of the
server, the same string which is used to identify the server in their
PKI certificate, so the moniker "S" in CPace, QUAKE, or CPaceQUAKE
could be a long-term identifier like the DNS name.  But there is no
stable counterpart for this on the user side, so "U" in CPace, QUAKE,
or CPaceQUAKE could be a short-term string.

I would also propose that userID is not an optional parameter in
GenVerifier, but S can be left as optional:  In all applications there
is some identifier the server associates with an account that stores
the "password file", i.e. tuple (salt, v, pk).  This account
identifier will in most applications be known to both user and server,
so I would think that userID is not optional.  But I guess it could be
left as optional too:  If someone wants to omit this identifier in
GenVerifiers then their password file could be e.g. used by an
attacker to attack other users who potentially share the same
password, but that's an option some implementer might want to make,
e.g. to allow for user account names to change without having to
regenerate password files (salt,v,pk) on the server.

I would also add a note, e.g. in the first paragraph of 6.1.1, that
"S" must be a long-term identifier, and perhaps add a note that that
if identifier "S" is used as an input and it changes (e.g. it is a DNS
name and that name changes) then the password verifier generated using
that "S" string would have to be regenerated.

By contrast, in the Password Confirmation protocol, i.e. section 6.2,
the client should have input just U as it is now (together with seed
derived using GenVerifiers).  This is because 6.2 specifies an on-line
protocol, which just like all the other protocols have these sid|U|S
session/party1/party2 identifiers as inputs.  What should change is
how the client generates the "seed" input to the Password
Confirmation, but that's outside section 6.2.

Here's a list of other related edits:
- in the first paragraph of section 6.1.1, change "To make verifiers
unique between different clients with the same password or servers
that they interact with, we employ a salt and optional client and
server identifiers." to "To make verifiers unique between different
users with the same password or servers that they interact with, we
employ a salt, a user account identifier, and an optional server
identifier." [I don't know how many of these input fields you want to
leave as optional.]
- in algorithms GenVerifierMaterial and GenVerifiers in section 6.1.1:
 change "U" to "userID" (including in the "Inputs:" specification)
- in the graph picture at the very end of section 6, in the first
line:  add "userID" to the Client's inputs
- in the same graph picture, in the 2nd line:  add "userID,S" to the
inputs to GenVerifierMaterial, unless you want to leave userID and/or
S because you want to treat them as optional inputs here?  (see
related issue in 6.1.2 below)


section 6.1.1, GenVerifiers:
Add KEM to the Parameters (you are using KEM.DeriveKeyPair here)

section 6.1.2: Registration:
In the "high-level" graph picture you state Client's inputs as "PRS,
salt", and these inputs should be extended by "userID, S", unless you
want to treat these as optional and leave them out for that reason?

section 6.2, graph picture just before section 6.2.1:
in the first line:  replace "PRS" with "seed" in the Client's inputs

section 6.2,
In the first paragraph of section 6.2, when you say that variable
"seed" is "derived from the password using a key stretching function",
should we add more specifically that it is derived using the
GenVerifierMaterial function?

sections 6.2.1 and 6.2.2:
why do you have a third argument "nil" to KDF.Extract that derives
prk_k_h1 and prk_k_h2 in PC-Challenge and PC-Response?
In all prior uses of the KDF.Extract you had only two arguments, the
"key related material" and the "context material", although there
could be effective keys in the context material as well, like r and T
in Feistel hashes in the QUAKE, and there can be context-related
materials in the first arguments as well.  For the sake of consistency
I would eliminate these ", nil" additional arguments in these two
KDF.Extract instances (in both PC-Challenge and PC-Response).

section 6.2.2:
in the PC-Response, you don't handle the possibility of the Decaps
error, and this is a CCA encryption so it can throw an error in
decryption.  I think you should handle it like you did in
QUAKE.Finish, i.e. use the "try [...] catch [...]" construct, e.g. I
suppose you would do this by replacing line:
k = KEM.Decaps(sk, c)
with two lines like this:
try k = KEM.Decaps(sk, c)
catch DecapsError: raise AuthenticationError
(?)

section 6.2.3:
I think you have an inconsistency in naming the client's message in
the inputs to PC-Verify:  You specify these inputs as "context,
response" in the "Inputs: [...]" part, but in the "def PC-Verify" line
the inputs are "context, server_confirm_target".

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
From @stanislawjarecki: These "comments on Section 6" have *two independent parts*, and the
second part should be less controversial, so in the interest of time
please go over the second part first:

1)  The first half of these comments is all about adding a new
"userID" field in section 6, and in particular replacing "U" with
"userID" in the inputs to GenVerifiers and GenVerifierMaterial.
2)  The second half, starting from "section 6.1.1, GenVerifiers:" is a
list of other edits which are about other issues (except "section
6.1.2: Registration:" which is still about adding the userID field)

The first part I believe is also important, but I also understand if
it's not a slam-dunk, and if it is controversial then I don't want
that to obscure the fact that there are other independent edits in the
second half of this post...

issues.title: Client use of verifier
issues.author: yannick-sierra
issues.body:
"In the asymmetric PAKE setting, the client first registers a password verifier with the server. A verifier is a value that is derived from the password and which the client will later use to demonstrate knowledge of the password."

In an asymmetric PAKE, the verifier is not expected to be usable to authenticate as the client. Should the second sentence say:
"which the server will later use to verify the client knowledge of the password"?

comments.author: stanislawjarecki
comments.body: Good point:  Yannick's edit makes it clearer.

issues.title: Does random() need to be deterministic?
issues.author: yannick-sierra
issues.body:
> The function random(n) generates a cryptographically secure pseudorandom byte string of length n bytes.

Why pseudorandom (ie deterministic)? I would expect a "Cryptographically Secure Random Number Generator" or something along this line. Otherwise, we should define it as a PRF?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: It's a good point, but "psuedorandom" is the usual way these this function is described (see e.g. RFC9180), so I think we should leave this as-is.

issues.title: KEM section
issues.author: yannick-sierra
issues.body:
> where seed SHOULD have Nseed bytes.

Nseed is a notation, I am not sure how to read the "should".
Did we mean to set a minimum side for Nseed that should be meet "where seed SHOULD have Nseed>128bytes" ?
Otherwise maybe say "where seed byte length is called "Nseed"?

comments.author: stanislawjarecki
comments.body:
I agree, shouldn't the line in "DeriveKeyPair(seed)" algorithm in section 4.1 say instead that:
"seed MUST have Nseed bytes"
?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: The intent here is to say that the seed should have at least `Nseed` bytes. We use SHOULD to match RFC9180 terminology on the amount of entropy provided in seeds. See [this](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9180#name-derivekeypair) for the specific language.

comments.author: yannick-sierra
comments.body:
Is `seed` considered like a buffer? What does it mean for seed to have byte size not being "Nseed"?

I am looking at the following statement later in the doc and trying to make sense of it when "seed" has a byte size which is not Nseed.
`seed = random(BUKEM.Nseed)`

If |seed| < Nseed, is this an implicit truncation which could impact the security?

comments.author: yannick-sierra
comments.body: not an issue blocking the first draft, I am trying to understand the feedback above.

comments.author: stanislawjarecki
comments.body: I had a related comment in part (III) of the comments I just posted and emailed.  The comment is that there seems to be two parameters Nseed, related to two KEMs, i.e. BUKEM and KEM.  The current draft uses one constant mame for both but in BUKEM key generation (used in OQUAKE) it renders it as BUKEM.Nseed, but in KEM key generation (used in CPaceOQUAKE+) it doesn't link it to the underlying KEM.

comments.author: stanislawjarecki
comments.body:
I'm copying that point from my comments below (together with a related point about constant Nsecret):
-----------

*)  In section 5.2 (OQUAKE), you disambiguate the Nseed constant as
the BUKEM one, and you refer to it as "BUKEM.Nseed" in OQUAKE.Init in
the line that computes seed = random(BUKEM.Nseed).  You also list
BUKEM in the Parameters of OQUAKE.Init.  But in section 6.1
(CPaceOQUAKE+, Registering Clients), in GenVerifierMaterial you use
"Nseed" to refer to the KEM constant (not BUKEM), and you don't
include KEM in the Parameters of GenVerifierMateriaI.  I think this is
underspecified, and you should:
- Include KEM in Parameters of GenVerifierMaterial
- replace "Nseed" with "KEM.Nseed" in *two* lines in GenVerifierMaterial

Related edit:  In "The RECOMMENDED parameters" paragraph in section 7
(CPaceOQUAKE+ Configurations), you say that Nseed = 32, but its not
clear if that's KEM.Nseed, which should be X-Wing.Nseed, or its
BUKEM.Nseed, which should be ML-BUKEM758.Nseed.  Maybe they are both
32 bytes, but I think that in this list of recommended parameters the
Nseed should be broken into two parameters:
KEM.Nseed = 32(?)
BUKEM.Nseed = 32(?)
and then this will agree with the two Nseed uses, one as BUKEM.Nseed
in OQUAKE.Init code and the other as KEM.Nseed in GenVerifierMaterial.

*)  Somewhat related:  In your recommended parameters you do not
specify what you expect Nsecret to be, which is the length of the
shared secret key in KEM or BUKEM.  (On the other hand, you can skip
parameter Nsk in section 4.1: I think this parameter is not used
anywhere.)

comments.author: stanislawjarecki
comments.body:
Also, I just checked that X-Wing specifies the KeyGen input as 32 byte string.

However, I don't see a specification of ML-KEM KeyGen which takes an outside seed.  Our draft refers to Kemeleon draft for BUKEM, i.e. https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-veitch-kemeleon-00, but in that draft the only specification of KeyGen I see is a reference to NIST.FIPS.203 which specifies ML-KEM, and there KeyGen doesn't take outside seed *and* its internal seed is *64* bytes, see https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.203.pdf, page 35.

Judging by this we should specify KEM.Nseed (= X-Wing Nseed) as 32 and BUKEM.Nseed (= ML-KEM Nseed) as 64.

[Bur let me know if the IETF description of ML-KEM specifies KeyGen interfaces differently and specify the seed length differently!]

issues.author: yannick-sierra
issues.body: The current document has a reference to the ML-KEM draft `{{FIPS203-Draft}}` and should refer to the standard one instead.

comments.body: Addressed as part of #15.

issues.title: Replace Argon with Scrypt
issues.author: yannick-sierra
issues.body:
We need to use Scrypt, not Argon.
Scrypt is more widely available that Argon, and its uses SPAKE2+ under the hood which is relevant when NIST functions are needed.

PC-KSF: Argon2id(S = zeroes(16), p = 4, T = Nh, m = 2^21, t = 1, v = 0x13, K = nil, X = nil, y = 2) {{!ARGON2=RFC9106}}


Scrypt: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7914.html

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Argon is the preferred MHF function for CFRG specifications. We can add a configuration that uses Scrypt if needed, though. I'll leave this open to track that.

comments.author: yannick-sierra
comments.body: Adding Scrypt as a different configuration is fine but feels necessary. That can be in the next draft version.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Fixed [directly on main](https://github.com/chris-wood/draft-pqpake/commit/4a3aec1cd6bf815fe6a07afc0369e7ad2d5ae496).

issues.title: Reduce number of acronyms: ex DST -> Domain
issues.author: yannick-sierra
issues.body:
Acronyms are a necessity for brevity but also make the read of a technical document more difficult.
Short plain english words like "Seed" are easier and I think DST could be replaced by "DomainString" or "Domain" for example.
There may be other ones too.

comments.author: stanislawjarecki
comments.body:
I would push back on this because "DST" is used in many lines of code (there are currently 49 places in code where this acronym is used), so replacing it with longer string will make all these lines longer.

Also, as far as I can see each such code where DST is used includes this line in the "Parameters" section, which reminds the reader what this acronym stands for:
- DST, domain separation tag, a byte string

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: In general I agree with the sentiment, but for DST in particular I think we should keep it as-is since it's used in the code and every reference is defined in the function that uses it (as Stas says). If there are other acronyms we can or should simplify, let's file issues to do it.

issues.title: comments on citations
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
some comments to citations:

1)  We currently have two citations for [CPACE] and [CPace]:  They are the same and should be merged.

2)  We currently cite Beguinet, H., Chevalier, C., Pointcheval, D., Ricosset, T., and M. Rossi, "GeT a CAKE [...]" paper for [QUAKE], but this is not correct because the [BCPRR'23] paper had a very similar protocol, but it was using an ideal cipher to password-encrypt the KEM public key, while QUAKE uses 2-Feistel.  I think that the primary citation for the QUAKE protocol should be our NoIC paper, i.e.

[ABJ25] 
Afonso Arriaga, Manuel Barbosa, and Stanislaw Jarecki, "NoIC: PAKE from KEM without Ideal Ciphers", Cryptology ePrint Archive, Paper 2025/231, February 2025, <https://eprint.iacr.org/2025/231>.

In terms of edits, here is what I would propose:
*) remove citation to [QUAKE] and add citation to [ABJ25]
*) don't cite anyone in the 2nd line of section 5 (currently it cites [QUAKE])
*) instead, change the first line of section 5.1 to mention [ABJ25], e.g.:
"QUAKE is a PAKE built from a BUKEM and KDF, using a 2-rounds of Feistel network to password-encrypt the BUKEM public key. The QUAKE protocol is based on the "NoIC" protocol analyzed in [ABJ25]."

(The [ABJ25] protocol is based on a chain of prior works, including the CAKE paper, and several others.  Also [JRX24] analyze a different variant of this protocol, but it is not a variant which we are proposing in this IETF draft.  I understand that in IETF draft you don't typically cite the whole lines of work, and give just one reference, and if someone is interested they can find the related prior work in this reference?  In that case citing [ABJ25] is enough.)

3) In CPaceQUAKE section we should mention the Hesse-Rosenberg and the Lyu-Liu papers: 

[HR24]
Julia Hesse and Michael Rosenberg, "PAKE Combiners and Efficient Post-Quantum Instantiations", Cryptology ePrint Archive, Paper 2024/1621, October 2024, <https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/1621>.

[LL24]
You Lyu and Shengli Liu, "Hybrid Password Authentication Key Exchange in the UC Framework", Cryptology ePrint Archive, Paper 2024/1630, October 2024, <https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/1630>.

And somewhere among the 5 introductory paragraphs of Section 5.3 (On Composition of CPace and QUAKE) we should add a small paragraph with something like this:
"The CPaceQUAKE protocol is based on the `Sequential PAKE Combiner' protocol proposed by [HR24].  A very close variant of this protocol was also analyzed in [LL24]."

4) In CPaceQUAKE+ section we should mention the Lyu, Liu, Han paper, and Yanqi's PhD thesis as closely related protocols:

[LLH24]
You Lyu, Shengli Liu, and Shuai Han, "Efficient Asymmetric PAKE Compiler from KEM and AE", Cryptology ePrint Archive, Paper 2024/1400, September 2024, <https://eprint.iacr.org/2024/1400>.

[Gu24,
Yanqi Gu, "New Paradigms For Efficient Password Authentication Protocols", PhD Thesis, University of California, Irvine, June 2024, <https://www.escholarship.org/uc/item/7qm0220s>.

After the introductory paragraph of section 6, just before section 6.1, we should add a small paragraph with something like this:
"The CPaceQUAKE+ protocol can be seen as a close variant (and a specific instance) of the `augmented PAKE' construction presented in [LLH24] and in [Gu24]."

issues.title: simple editorial comments (added March 17 at noon)
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
(I)  more important and simple edits:

*) In CPace.Finish you have a line which now reads:
K = G.scalar_mult_vfy(yb, Ya)
but it should be:
K = G.scalar_mult_vfy(ya, Yb)

*) CPace.Finish inputs are defined as (PRS, ya, Yb, sid) but when you
call it in CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish, you call it on inputs
(ctx1,msg2,sid,U,S).
Here ctx1 = ya, and msg2 = Yb, but:
-  "U,S" inputs are not needed,
-  the PRS input is missing.
PRS is actually not used in CPace.Finish, but I assume you listed PRS
in CPace.Finish inputs because CPace specification does it?  (Can you
check?)
If CPace.Finish inputs stay as (PRS,ya,Yb,sid) then the line that
calls CPace.Finish in CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish should be:
key1 = CPace.Finish(PRS, ctx1, msg2, sid)

*) OQUAKE.Respond inputs are defined as (PRS, init_msg, sid, U, S),
but then CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish you call OQUAKE.Respond on inputs
(PRS2, extended_sid, msg3, Nkey, U, S).  I think this line should be:
key2, msg4 = OQUAKE.Respond(PRS2, msg3, extended_sid, U, S)

*) CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish inputs are defined as (PRS, (ctx1, s1),
(msg2, msg3, s2), sid, U, S), but in the first three lines you decode
s1,msg2,msg3 from resp_msg.  Also, s2 is the first item in resp_msg,
not the last item.  I think these inputs should be defined as
def InitiatorFinish(PRS, (ctx1, s1), resp_msg, sid, U, S).
[this would be consistent with the way you define inputs to CPaceOQUAKE.Respond

Also, I think the decoding of resp_msg in InitiatorFinish is
underspecified:  Right now you don't say where msg2 ends, so len(msg2)
is not well defined in the line that decodes msg3.

*)  On related note, in the arrow-drawing picture showing CPaceOQUAKE
flows just before 5.3.1, you write that messages are "msg1, s1" and
"msg2, msg3, s2" but in the implementation they are "s1, msg1" and
"s2, msg2, msg3".  Likewise the ordering of these should be like the
latter in the inputs to CPaceOQUAKE.Respond and
CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish

*) in the references, the [SPAKE2PLUS] reference renders "*** BROKEN
REFERENCE ***" for me.

*)  Perhaps I don't understand the notation for substring references
you use, but I want to confirm this.  Currently when you parse strings
into fragments, which I think happens in these 4 cases:
resp_msg in OQUAKE.Finish,
init_msg in CPaceOQUAKE.Respond,
resp_msg in CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish,
verifier_seed in GenVerifierMaterial
your reference ranges intersect.
Specifically, your references look like this:
resp_msg[0..Npk] and resp_msg[Npk..]
init_msg[0..32] and init_msg[32..]
resp_msg: [similar as above]
verifier_seed[0:Nverifier] and verifier_seed[Nverifier:Nverifier + Nseed]

Does this use a notation where S[i..j] refers to a substring of S
which starts at position i and ends at position (j-1)?  For example,
if S="abcde" then S[0,1]="a", S[0,3]="abc", and S[3,5]="de"?  If so,
then the above references are fine, but I want to make sure because
I'm used to a notation where S[i..j] refers to a substring of S which
ends at position j and not (j-1), in which case S[0,1]="ab",
S[0,3]="abcd", and S[3,5] is undefined because |S|=5.

*) In the graph showing flows of CPaceOQUAKE+ at the end of section 7:
CPaceOQUAKE.InitiatorFinish inputs in this picture are listed as
(v,ctx1,msg2,32,sid,U,S), which is correct except for the "32" value,
i.e. it should be (v,ctx1,msg2,32,sid,U,S).


---------------------
(II) less important, but most should be quick:

*) Section 5, first paragraph:  in the last sentence you call this
protocol "QUAKE" rather than "OQUAKE".

*) section 6.2, 2nd paragraph, "derived from the the
GenVerifierMaterial function" -> "derived from the GenVerifierMaterial
function"

*)  In references, some of the <[https://eprint.iacr.org/[...]](https://eprint.iacr.org/%5B...%5D)> links
go to pdf's and some to the abstracts.  I would uniformize them and
make them all link to the abstracts, e.g.
<https://eprint.iacr.org/2025/1630>, because the eprint abstract pages
link to the pdf's.'

*)  this is nitpicking but for some Extract(....) outputs you use
convention prk_[name] and for some you use [name]_prk.  In the order
of occurrence we have:
prk_T_pad
prk_s_pad
prk_sk
extended_sid_prk
PRS2_prk
sessionkey_prk
prk_k_h1
prk_k_h2
(so it seems that the three [name]_prk variables are all in CPaceOQUAKE)

*) in the conceptual picture at the beginning of section 5.3, under
paragraph starting with "This is outlined in the diagram below", which
shows conceptually the sequential PAKE combiner, I think it would be
clearer if you added some lines to this picture, and did this:
1)  make the "OQUAKE protocol" box clearly output just one value, denoted SK2,
2)  use downward arrows on both sides of the "OQUAKE protocol" box, to
show that this SK2 is inserted into the H(...,SK2) expressions which
outputs the final "Session key" on both sides.

issues.title: Continued edits
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
(III) important but maybe less immediate:

*)  In section 5.2 (OQUAKE), you disambiguate the Nseed constant as
the BUKEM one, and you refer to it as "BUKEM.Nseed" in OQUAKE.Init in
the line that computes seed = random(BUKEM.Nseed).  You also list
BUKEM in the Parameters of OQUAKE.Init.  But in section 6.1
(CPaceOQUAKE+, Registering Clients), in GenVerifierMaterial you use
"Nseed" to refer to the KEM constant (not BUKEM), and you don't
include KEM in the Parameters of GenVerifierMateriaI.  I think this is
underspecified, and you should:
- Include KEM in Parameters of GenVerifierMaterial
- replace "Nseed" with "KEM.Nseed" in *two* lines in GenVerifierMaterial

Related edit:  In "The RECOMMENDED parameters" paragraph in section 7
(CPaceOQUAKE+ Configurations), you say that Nseed = 32, but its not
clear if that's KEM.Nseed, which should be X-Wing.Nseed, or its
BUKEM.Nseed, which should be ML-BUKEM758.Nseed.  Maybe they are both
32 bytes, but I think that in this list of recommended parameters the
Nseed should be broken into two parameters:
KEM.Nseed = 32(?)
BUKEM.Nseed = 32(?)
and then this will agree with the two Nseed uses, one as BUKEM.Nseed
in OQUAKE.Init code and the other as KEM.Nseed in GenVerifierMaterial.

*)  Somewhat related:  In your recommended parameters you do not
specify what you expect Nsecret to be, which is the length of the
shared secret key in KEM or BUKEM.  (On the other hand, you can skip
parameter Nsk in section 4.1: I think this parameter is not used
anywhere.)

*)  The two usages of KDF.Extract in PC-Challenge and PC-Response
(section 6.2), are different then other KDF.Extract uses.

In OQUAKE and CPaceOQUAKE we use KDF.Extract on inputs (seed, IKM)
where seed = PRS or seed = s1|s2, but the latter case is special
because there are no secrets in derivation of extended_sid so we just
need that the KDF.Extract+Expand function is CRH on (s1|s2).

However, in PC-Challenge and PC-Response we make seed = confirm_input
or confirm_input || k, and IKM = DST || [hname].  In other words, we
put very long byte strings into seed, and short and public strings
into IKM.  KDF.Extract(seed,IKM) = HMAC-Hash(seed,IKM), i.e. seed is
supposed to be a "salt", and IKM is the long string containing keying
material.

I would remove SK from confirm_input string and put only SK into the
seed, i.e. I would do this:

confirm_input = encode_sid(sid, U, S) || enc_c || transcript
prk_k_h1 = KDF.Extract(SK, DST || "h1" || confirm_input)
prk_k_h2 = KDF.Extract(SK, DST || "h2" || confirm_input || k)

issues.title: key derivation in OQUAKE:  change needed in CFRG draft
issues.author: stanislawjarecki
issues.body:
I just noticed that in our CFRG draft, [https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-vos-cfrg-pqpake/], we made a mistake in the key derivation for OQUAKE.  Its done in OQUAKE.Respond and OQUAKE.Finish, sections 5.2.2 and 5.2.3, and the mistake is in the current line:

prk_sk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "OQUAKE" || fullsid || k)

which should instead read as follows:

prk_sk = KDF.Extract(PRS, DST || "OQUAKE" || fullsid || (s,T) || pk || ct || k)

[alternatively, instead of "(s,T)" we write "s || T"] 

The "prk_sk" value is an input to KDF.Expand which generates (key,h), i.e. respectively the final output session key and the key confirmation value, and these are derived in NoIC via an RO hash on inputs (fullsid, pw, apk, pk, ct, k), and here apk=(s,T).  In the prior version of the writeup it was almost as in NoIC except value "pk" was omitted, but the CFRG version is as if this hash only took (fullsid, pw, k), and that wouldn't bind to the transcript (apk,ct), and adding "pk" to these inputs simplifies the NoIC proof (and since there doesn't seem to be any extra cost involved in adding "pk" to the inputs we should do it just so we can invoke the security proof for NoIC as a black-box).

I'm putting these changes in the writeup, but we should make them in the CFRG draft.

issues.title: Fixing the number of bytes of a ciphertext
issues.author: jellevos
issues.body:
As pointed out by Dan Harkins in private communications, the currrent version of the spec says that `Nct` is 1514, but this is exactly the number you would get after applying Kemeleon, which is wrong. The correct number should be 1088.

Next to that, in the `Finish` function, we should use the constant `Nct` instead of `Npk`.
